links.title: It's tough being an Azure fan
links.description:
Azure has never been the #1 cloud provider - that spot continues to belong
to AWS, which is the category leader. However, in most people’s minds, it has
been a pretty reasonable #2, and while not necessarily vastly differentiated
from AWS there are enough things to write home about.
However, even as a user and somewhat of a fan of the Azure technology, it is
proving increasing difficult to recommend.

links.title: Visualizing the Fourier Series
links.description: In this notebook I implement a classic visualization of the Fourier series where we approximate a square wave from a series of sinusoids. With the help of Daniel from the Coding Train. The sinusoids are defined by: We can visualize each series as a recursive set of circles. The radius of circle   is   and then we place another circle   moving around the circumference of circle  . The location of the circle's centers is determined by:

links.title: Fourier Series (part2): Alien 👾 machines
links.description: In Part 1 we used a series of sinusoids to approximate a square wave. In this notebook we take a step further and we compute the Discrete Fourier Series on a svg path. The result is a same-length (as the number of points in the input path) equally space samples. We apply the DFT to the x and y values separately and we visualize those as epicycles connecting their state to the path we are aproximating. As usual, I stand on the shoulders of giants....

Atul Gawande’s The Checklist Manifesto was originally published in 2009. By the
time I read it a few years ago, the hard-earned lessons explained in this book
had already trickled into hospitals across North America. It’s easy to look at
the core concept and think of it as trivial. For decades, though, it was
anything but obvious.

Atul Gawande walks readers through his experience of how the modern medical
system fails. The 20th century saw vast ...

links.title:
A Brief History of LessWrong
 - LessWrong
links.description:
In 2006, Eliezer Yudkowsky, Robin Hanson, and others began writing on Overcoming
Bias, a group blog with the general theme of how to move one’s beliefs closer to
reality despite biases such as overconfidence and wishful thinking. In 2009,
after the topics drifted more widely, Eliezer moved to a new community blog,
LessWrong.

LessWrong was seeded with series of daily blog posts written by Eliezer,
originally known as The Sequences, and more recen...

links.title: Does Advertising Actually Work? (Part 2: Digital) (Ep. 441) - Freakonomics
links.description: Google and Facebook are worth a combined $2 trillion, with the vast majority of their revenue coming from advertising. In our previous episode, we learned that TV advertising is much less effective than the industry says. Is digital any better? Some say yes, some say no — and some say we’re in a full-blown digital-ad bubble.
